newsitem.title: INDIA: FEATURE-Empire builders banished to Bombay zoo.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE-Empire builders banished to Bombay zoo.

text.p: Hidden in Bombay's zoo a headless brother of the Duke of Wellington gathers dust with eight other stony relics of the British Raj in India.
The statue of Lord Wellesley, who conquered large tracts of India with his illustrious younger brother, is not the only former governor general of India without a head.
Lord Cornwallis was also beheaded during a night attack on statues of Britain's Empire builders in August 1965.
Fearing more trouble, civic authorities gave the statues refuge in a gloomy backyard of the Bhau Daji Lad Museum (formerly the Victoria & Albert Museum), located in the zoo's grounds.
"The statues were shifted here in 1965 as a result of a movement in the city for the removal of all public colonial statues," Suman Tate, research assistant at the museum, told Reuters.
"Just horrible things were done to these valuable statues," Foy Nissen, a local Bombay historian said.
VICTORIA BEHEADED

Queen Victoria, the Empress of India, escaped the Indian nationalists' attack with a battered crown, but suffered the ignominy of losing her head in transit during the rescue operation and had to have it stuck back on later.
Her son the future Edward VII fared better.
The statue of Albert Edward, the then Prince of Wales, astride a black horse, greets visitors at the gates of the zoo.
But most of these symbols of Bombay's colonial past remain skeletons in the cupboard, while the city prepares to celebrate 50 years of Indian independence.

The statues became the focus of nationalist fervour some 18 years after the last British troops filed through the Gateway of India, a triumphal arch on Bombay's waterfront, to sail home as the sun began to set on the empire.
George Fernandes, a current member of parliament, led the move to rid the streets of these reminders of British power.
"I thought someone just had to take the initiative for their removal," Fernandes, leader of the Samata party, allied to the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, said.
CONTRAST WITH POMP AND PAGEANTRY
A reawakening of nationalist spirit followed the death of Jawaharlal Nehru, India's first prime minister in 1964, he said.

The statues were removed by authorities following a threat by Fernandes that the valuable bronze equestrian statue of the Prince of Wales, by world-renowned sculptor Boehm, would be dislodged by activists on Independence Day, August 15.
"This really was a contrast to the pomp and pageantry that attended the public unveiling of this statue on June 26th, 1879," said Nissen.
The Kala Ghoda (black horse), as the statue came to be known locally, was a gift to the city of Bombay by Sir Albert Sassoon, son of the Bombay Jewish merchant, David Sassoon.
The Kala Ghoda commemorated the visit of the Prince of Wales to Bombay in 1875-76, and cost 12,500 sterling.
So famous a landmark was this statue that the area in which it once stood continues to be referred to as Kala Ghoda.
"These statues all represent a certain social ethos characteristic of the last century," explains Nissen.
"It was fashionable for prominent merchants or groups of people to make such a gift to the city. They earned a lot of kudos for it."
OPIUM AND COTTON FUND STATUARY
The nineteenth century was a prosperous period for Bombay. Huge family fortunes were made, at first in the opium and cotton trade, and later in the cotton mill industry.
Merchants turned philanthropists to give back a little to the city that gave them so much.
"Besides, statues in Bombay were erected to commemorate specific historic events and honour personalities who contributed to the city," comments social historian Sharada Dwivedi.
The statue of Sir Patrick Kelly, Bombay police commissioner from 1922 to 1933, was erected by popular public subscription.
This statue, now another sad inmate of the museum's hidden statuary, originally stood in front of the Bombay Police Headquarters.
"The statues were part of the urban landscape. They were beautiful and valuable pieces of public sculpture," Nissen said.
Now the places where they once stood tall either lie vacant or have been built over. Or they have been co-opted to give expression to Indian nationalist aspirations.
"A case in point is the lion and lioness from the statue of Lord Hardinge of Penhurst, viceroy and governor-general of India from 1910 to 1916," says Nissen.
"They adorn the pedestal of radical Indian nationalist leader Lokmanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak on Chowpatty beach."
By a twist of fate, Tilak's statue was the starting point of the city's Freedom March on August 9, the first of numerous programmes planned to mark 50 years of Indian Independence.
